author: g11tech
content: using above: this is a  naive block+blobs arrival projection  for mainnet:  https://twitter.com/Gajpower/status/1713488067086987664

author: g11tech
content:
so looking at percentile, num blobs grid: we can make an informed choice by choosing a target arrival ETA and a target percentile, i think it would make sense for the block+all blobs to be available before 4 seconds so that the imported block can get proposer boost, and 95 percentile seems to be a good target

Surprisingly it is leading to max blobs=4, cc <@758579010027782144> <@578356786889752586>

author: parithosh
content:
Dencun-devnet-10 planning time, please link which branch we should be using. It should support the latest trusted setup file (the final one that will go into mainnet), found here: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/3521

Specs here: https://notes.ethereum.org/@ethpandaops/dencun-devnet-10

author: pk910
content:
Hi everyone,

We've continuously been spamming devnet9 with blobs over the weekend.
I've now just grabbed a few statistics about the blob inclusion from different clients.

It basically shows how many of the proposed blocks contain at least one blob sidecar.
As the tx pool had a few blob transactions all the time, we'd have expected all clients to include blobs at a similar rate.

But what we can see is that some client pairs produce much less blocks with blobs than others.
Especially erigon & ethereumjs pairs look a bit bad.

author: pk910
content:
The table shows data from slot 102400 to 123550 (basically the weekend).
`teku/geth` was expected to behave bad as it is proposing bad blocks.

author: pk910
content:
In average, 69% of the blocks did contain at least 1 blob, which was expected when spamming blocks due to the blob fee mechanism.
Everything below 50% looks a bit bad I'd say ðŸ˜‰

author: tersec
content: looks like it's mostly a function of EL, not CL

author: parithosh
content: also a caveat is that besu has more resources allocated to it compared to the other ELs ðŸ˜„
